segment.source: Scan from your app
segment.target: Scan from your app

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Windows.Devices.Scanners
segment.target: Windows.Devices.Scanners

segment.source: DeviceInformation
segment.target: DeviceInformation

segment.source: DeviceClass
segment.target: DeviceClass

segment.source: Learn here how to scan content from your app by using a flatbed, feeder, or auto-configured scan source.
segment.target: Learn here how to scan content from your app by using a flatbed, feeder, or auto-configured scan source.

segment.source: Important The Windows.Devices.Scanners APIs are part of the desktop device family.
segment.target: Important The Windows.Devices.Scanners APIs are part of the desktop device family.

segment.source: Apps can use these APIs only on the desktop version of Windows 10.
segment.target: Apps can use these APIs only on the desktop version of Windows 10.

segment.source: To scan from your app, you must first list the available scanners by declaring a new DeviceInformation object and getting the DeviceClass type.
segment.target: To scan from your app, you must first list the available scanners by declaring a new DeviceInformation object and getting the DeviceClass type.

segment.source: Only scanners that are installed locally with WIA drivers are listed and available to your app.
segment.target: Only scanners that are installed locally with WIA drivers are listed and available to your app.

segment.source: After your app has listed available scanners, it can use the auto-configured scan settings based on the scanner type, or just scan using the available flatbed or feeder scan source.
segment.target: After your app has listed available scanners, it can use the auto-configured scan settings based on the scanner type, or just scan using the available flatbed or feeder scan source.

segment.source: To use auto-configured settings, the scanner must be enabled for auto-configuration must not be equipped with both a flatbed and a feeder scanner.
segment.target: To use auto-configured settings, the scanner must be enabled for auto-configuration must not be equipped with both a flatbed and a feeder scanner.

segment.source: For more info, see Auto-Configured Scanning.
segment.target: For more info, see Auto-Configured Scanning.

segment.source: Enumerate available scanners
segment.target: Enumerate available scanners

segment.source: Windows does not detect scanners automatically.
segment.target: Windows does not detect scanners automatically.

segment.source: You must perform this step in order for your app to communicate with the scanner.
segment.target: You must perform this step in order for your app to communicate with the scanner.

segment.source: In this example, the scanner device enumeration is done using the Windows.Devices.Enumeration namespace.
segment.target: In this example, the scanner device enumeration is done using the Windows.Devices.Enumeration namespace.

segment.source: First, add these using statements to your class definition file.
segment.target: First, add these using statements to your class definition file.

segment.source: Next, implement a device watcher to start enumerating scanners.
segment.target: Next, implement a device watcher to start enumerating scanners.

segment.source: For more info, see Enumerate devices.
segment.target: For more info, see Enumerate devices.

segment.source: Create an event handler for when a scanner is added.
segment.target: Create an event handler for when a scanner is added.

segment.source: Scan
segment.target: Scan

segment.source: Get an ImageScanner object
segment.target: Get an ImageScanner object

segment.source: For each ImageScannerScanSource enumeration type, whether it's Default, AutoConfigured, Flatbed, or Feeder, you must first create an ImageScanner object by calling the ImageScanner.FromIdAsync method, like this.
segment.target: For each ImageScannerScanSource enumeration type, whether it's Default, AutoConfigured, Flatbed, or Feeder, you must first create an ImageScanner object by calling the ImageScanner.FromIdAsync method, like this.

segment.source: Just scan
segment.target: Just scan

segment.source: To scan with the default settings, your app relies on the Windows.Devices.Scanners namespace to select a scanner and scans from that source.
segment.target: To scan with the default settings, your app relies on the Windows.Devices.Scanners namespace to select a scanner and scans from that source.

segment.source: No scan settings are changed.
segment.target: No scan settings are changed.

segment.source: The possible scanners are auto-configure, flatbed, or feeder.
segment.target: The possible scanners are auto-configure, flatbed, or feeder.

segment.source: This type of scan will most likely produce a successful scan operation, even if it scans from the wrong source, like flatbed instead of feeder.
segment.target: This type of scan will most likely produce a successful scan operation, even if it scans from the wrong source, like flatbed instead of feeder.

segment.source: Note If the user places the document to scan in the feeder, the scanner will scan from the flatbed instead.
segment.target: Note If the user places the document to scan in the feeder, the scanner will scan from the flatbed instead.

segment.source: If the user tries to scan from an empty feeder, the scan job won't produce any scanned files.
segment.target: If the user tries to scan from an empty feeder, the scan job won't produce any scanned files.

segment.source: Scan from Auto-configured, Flatbed, or Feeder source
segment.target: Scan from Auto-configured, Flatbed, or Feeder source

segment.source: Your app can use the device's Auto-Configured Scanning to scan with the most optimal scan settings.
segment.target: Your app can use the device's Auto-Configured Scanning to scan with the most optimal scan settings.

segment.source: With this option, the device itself can determine the best scan settings, like color mode and scan resolution, based on the content being scanned.
segment.target: With this option, the device itself can determine the best scan settings, like color mode and scan resolution, based on the content being scanned.

segment.source: The device selects the scan settings at run time for each new scan job.
segment.target: The device selects the scan settings at run time for each new scan job.

segment.source: Note Not all scanners support this feature, so the app must check if the scanner supports this feature before using this setting.
segment.target: Note Not all scanners support this feature, so the app must check if the scanner supports this feature before using this setting.

segment.source: In this example, the app first checks if the scanner is capable of auto-configuration and then scans.
segment.target: In this example, the app first checks if the scanner is capable of auto-configuration and then scans.

segment.source: To specify either flatbed or feeder scanner, simply replace AutoConfigured with Flatbed or Feeder.
segment.target: To specify either flatbed or feeder scanner, simply replace AutoConfigured with Flatbed or Feeder.

segment.source: Preview the scan
segment.target: Preview the scan

segment.source: You can add code to preview the scan before scanning to a folder.
segment.target: You can add code to preview the scan before scanning to a folder.

segment.source: In the example below, the app checks if the Flatbed scanner supports preview, then previews the scan.
segment.target: In the example below, the app checks if the Flatbed scanner supports preview, then previews the scan.

segment.source: Cancel the scan
segment.target: Cancel the scan

segment.source: You can let users cancel the scan job midway through a scan, like this.
segment.target: You can let users cancel the scan job midway through a scan, like this.

segment.source: Scan with progress
segment.target: Scan with progress

segment.source: Create a System.Threading.CancellationTokenSource object.
segment.target: Create a System.Threading.CancellationTokenSource object.

segment.source: Set up the progress event handler and get the progress of the scan.
segment.target: Set up the progress event handler and get the progress of the scan.

segment.source: Scanning to the pictures library
segment.target: Scanning to the pictures library

segment.source: Users can scan to any folder dynamically using the FolderPicker class, but you must declare the Pictures Library capability in the manifest to allow users to scan to that folder.
segment.target: Users can scan to any folder dynamically using the FolderPicker class, but you must declare the Pictures Library capability in the manifest to allow users to scan to that folder.

segment.source: For more info on app capabilities, see App capability declarations.
segment.target: For more info on app capabilities, see App capability declarations.
